replies.bodyText:
I think lite members were mainly introduced as a more performant client or to server as executors. Your cluster won't use any less memory if you add a lite member to it.
https://docs.hazelcast.org/docs/4.0.3/manual/html-single/index.html#enabling-lite-members
I think they are just ignored by Jet.
replies.author: viliam-durina

replies.bodyText: Well, I did not see any benefit from using these lite members. I thought the user must have an extra reason to use a nonhomogenous cluster of lite members and data members, e.g. a user may want to avoid memory usage on some of the cluster members.
replies.author: ufukyilmaz

timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -138,6 +138,7 @@ The most important properties are listed here:
 |------|:------|----------|
 |hazelcast.partition.count|271|Total number of partitions in the cluster.|
 |hazelcast.logging.type|jdk|What logger should be used by Jet. Valid options are `log4j`, `log4j2`, `slf4j` and `none`|
+|hazelcast.lite-member.enabled|false|Specifies whether the IMDG instance behind the Jet is data member or lite member. In our case where IMDG is used as Jet data storage, we recommend that you do not change the default value, as it increases the latency, the default value is false, i.e., data member. The reason for this latency increase is that accessing data in IMDG partitions has to contain network calls in the lite member. Besides, Jet needs at least one data member in the cluster to run jobs because job coordination primitives are kept in IMDG data structures.|
